ALLEGATION:
The agency placed a foster child in a home prior to the home being licensed.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/27/2022 I spoke with Foster Parent X by telephone. Foster Parent X reported
Child A, who is not a relative, was placed into her home on 6/30/2021, prior to her
becoming licensed as a foster parent. The agency called her about Child A’s
placement on 6/29/2021. She was surprised by the call, but the agency informed her
they were separating Child A and her sister, and they needed a placement for Child
A. Child A was placed with her on 6/30/2021, not 7/8/2021 which is the actual date
of her license. The agency provided her with an emergency medical consent
document. The document was dated 6/30/2021 and had Child A’s Medicaid and
social security number on it. She received a foster care replacement checklist with
that same date. The agency did not complete all the paperwork for Child A’s
placement until 7/14/2021.
On 2/2/2022 I spoke with Program Manager 2 onsite, and Director 1 was available
by telephone, about the complaint. I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3, and
Licensing Supervisor 4 onsite on 2/2/2022. Each of these staff acknowledged that
Child A is not a relative to Foster Parent X.
 FCW 3 reported Foster Parent X picked Child A up from the agency on
6/30/2021. Child A’s period of placement with Foster Parent X from
6/30/2021 until 7/8/2021 “was like respite”. The agency’s licensing
department spoke with DCWL (Division of Child Welfare Licensing) in
Lansing about the agency’s being able to have Child A placed with Foster
Parent X pending Foster Parent A’s official licensure. FCW 3 said Licensing
Supervisor 4 could better speak to the placement situation.
 Licensing Supervisor (LS) 4 acknowledged that Child A was placed in Foster
Parent X’s care on 6/30/2021, prior to Foster Parent X’s licensure. LS 4
advised that Foster Parent X’s foster family licensing evaluation (DHS- 3130)
3

package was already with DCWL for review and licensure; and the agency
attempted to get Foster Parent X’s license expedited. LS 4 called DCWL
Licensing Consultant 5 to try to execute that process. Licensing Consultant 5
informed LS 4 she would pull Foster Parent X’s package to the top for review
and processing. She contacted DCWL the following day (7/1/2021) and
discovered Foster Parent X’s home had yet to be approved for licensure.
She made another contact to DCWL one or two days later but was unable to
connect with Licensing Consultant 5 on this matter. She left a message. LS
4 admitted Licensing Consultant 5 never advised LS 4 or the agency they
could make the placement with Foster Parent X. Nor that Child A could be in
the home for at least 10 days without licensure. Director 1 informed of that
“based on her knowledge of the system”. LS 4 stated she felt comfortable
maintaining Child A’s placement with Foster Parent X because Director 1
reported they had 10 days to have the child placed in an unlicensed
unrelated home. LS 4 reported they did not complete a 3130 A (Children's
Foster Care Relative Placement Home Study) or Michigan Department of
Health and Human Service (MDHHS)-5770 Relative Placement Safety
Screen, because it was not a relative placement and they had completed a
full Initial Foster/Adoption Home Evaluation (CWL-3130) which included
fingerprint processing/criminal history and children protective services
checks. LS 4 acknowledged Child A’s placement shows in MISCAWIS as an
unrelated placement similar, to an unlicensed relative placement. She
surmised that the agency had to put it in the system that way so that it could
list the placement.
LS 4 reported a few days after her last contact to DCWL Foster Parent X’s
license was approved. The dates LS 4 reported as her contacts to DCWL did
not appear accurate given the fact that Foster Parent X’s 3130 was not
signed by LS 4 until 7/6/2021. LS 4 was initially not clear as to why that was.
On 2/10/2021 she advised me via email that the information that was given
me about the circumstances of Foster Parent X’s licensing/her contacts with
DCWL was due to her mixing-up of cases and events.
On 2/3/2021 I spoke with Licensing Consultant 5. She reported receiving the
documentation for Foster Parent X on 7/8/2021. The agency reported needing it
processed by 7/9/2021. She approved it and issued the license on 7/8/2021.
She never provided information to the agency on placing a child with Foster
Parent X prior to licensure; and the agency did not ask her about such. The only
way she knew that such a placement was possible was via a court order.
On 2/9/2022 I spoke with Director 1 about LS 4’s assertion that Director 1 had
knowledge that the agency could place Child A in a home for 10 days without
the person being licensed. Director 1 reported they placed Child A with Foster
Parent X because they had an emergency, and no other foster home for Child A
at the time. She advised she knew policy would allow that a child could be in a
respite/substitute care home for 10 days. She advised, in her opinion, it was
4

basically them placing Child A with a substitute care provider. Instead of the
prior foster parent providing that substitute care person, their agency found one
instead. She admitted Foster Parent X was not the substitute care provider for
Child A’s prior foster parent. She did not explore DHHS or other agencies for a
search of a possible license home for Child A. She saw the unlicensed
placement as temporary and that it was within policy guidelines.
Director 1 advised that the reason Child A was listed in MISACWIS as placed in
an unrelated caregiver home/ as if Foster Parent X was a relative is because it
was entered inappropriately. Program Manager 2 was trying to enter Child A’s
placement with Foster Parent X in MISACWIS. Program Manager 2 had the
incorrect date of 6/30/2021, did not have the full understanding around the
placement date, that it should have been 7/6/2021. Program Manager 2 sought
assistance from the MISACWIS Helpdesk and the Helpdesk somehow aided
Program Manager 2 in entering the placement. Thus, both the 6/30/2021
unrelated care placement and the later Foster Parent X licensed foster home
placements are listed.
On 2/18/2021 I spoke with DCWL Certification Program Manager 6. I explored
whether there was any policy or special way DCWL would allow a placement of a
child in an unlicensed home for foster care without that home being a relative.
DCWL Certification Program Manager 6 was not aware of such; other than by
court order, as reported DCWL Licensing Consultant 5. She recalled a
communication issuance release some time ago which attempted to provide
clarity on a what is a license foster home and whether a child can be out of such
a placement for more than 10 consecutive days. She provided me that
communication issuance. It is outlined below.
Reviewed
 Child A’s and Foster Parent X’s MISACWIS case records which showed:
 Child A was listed as placed with an “unrelated caregiver” Foster
Parent X on 6/30/2021 until 7/8/2021.
 Child A was listed as placed in a “licensed unrelated foster home” with
Foster Parent X on 7/8/2021 until 11/10/2021.
 A DHS-69 Action Summary dated 7/9/2021 showing Child A’s
placement change from an unlicensed relative home and listing that
change as 7/8/2021. This document indicated Child A’s birth parent
was notified of the move on 6/30/2021 and the child’s referring worker,
the court and LGAL (Lawyer Guardian Ad Litem) were notified on
7/8/2021.
 Documentation Foster Parent X was provided a copy of Child A’s
medical passport on 6/30/2021.
 Documentation that Child A was placed in Foster Parent X’s home “on
an emergency/respite basis due to the previous relative caregiver not
being willing to care for her any longer. The agency was awaiting
5

expedited licensure” of Foster Parent X’ s home “at the time of
placement”.
 Documentation in Foster Parent X’s MISACWIS screen like a DHS-
-
3130A-Children's Foster Care Relative Placement Home Study; and
MDHHS -5770 Relative Placement Safety Screen are completed
beginning 6/30/2021. The documents are listed as approved
7/14/2021 and 7/3/2021 respectively. Neither document is there.
 Foster Parent X’s Initial Foster/Adoption Home Evaluation (CWL-
3130) dated 7/6/2021 and approved by the licensing worker and
Licensing Supervisor 4 on 7/6/2021.
 The DCWL’s Bureau of Information Technology System (BITS) which
showed Foster Parent X’s Licensing home study package was received by
DCWL with an expedited approval request on 7/7/2021. The license was
approved/opened on 7/8/2021.
 Communication Issuance 17-168- Title Approved Absences from
Placement. The document indicated the following as it pertains to licensed
homes:
 A foster family home and foster family group home in MCL 722.111
et seq. (Act 116) is care and supervision that is provided 24 hours
a day, for 4 or more days a week, for 2 or more consecutive
weeks. Previously, this has been interpreted to mean that a child
may not be absent from a foster home for 11 or more consecutive
days unless placed in a licensed place/placement. This
Communication Issuance serves as clarification that MCL 722.111
et seq. (Act 116) does not limit the time that a child may be absent
from placement, but instead provides the statutory definition of a
foster family home and foster family group home. Therefore, the
following guidance is being issued to clarify timeframes and
requirements regarding a child’s absence from placement.
 An instance which a child can be in an approved absence from
their placement that does not require placement changes or
capacity changes to licensed foster homes include Substitute
Care, which is short term care and supervision for a foster child in
the absence of the caregiver. Substitute care is driven by the
caregiver’s need for substitute care. The substitute care provider
does not need to be a licensed provider. If the substitute care
provider is a licensed provider, a capacity change does not need to
occur.
 The approval path for the absence from placement cannot
override or interfere with the child’s case plan or court-ordered
requirements, such as parenting time. The provider must notify the
caseworker prior to the absence anytime a child will be out of their
placement 3 or more days. In addition, the child’s LGAL and
parents (for temporary wards) should be informed of planned
6

absences. Licensed foster homes must follow substitute care
licensing rule R 400.12319 and provide notification to the agency
before the beginning of any planned overnight substitute care and
within 24 hours of any unplanned absence requiring substitute care
for 24 hours or more.
 Absences of 3 to 5 days do not require approval beyond the
case worker. The placement must be considered intact; and
agree to remain actively involved with the child and/or his
family during the absence. The child’s placement is not
changed in MISACWIC, and payment may continue if the
placement is maintained, and the child’s return to the
placement is planned.
 Absences of 6 to 14 days require the foster care supervisor’s
approval. The placement must be considered intact by the
provider and return to the placement is planned. The child’s
placement is not changed in MISACWIC, and payment may
continue if the placement is maintained, and the child’s return
to placement is planned.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12404 Placement.
(1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is
legally related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a
licensed foster home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
ANALYSIS: The agency placed Child A in an unlicensed unrelated home for
eight days pending the home’s licensure. The placement was
against rule and policy standards. It did not meet the possible
exception of absence from placement in a substitute care
provider home as outlined in the communication issuance
clarification; because there was no plan for Child A to return to
her prior foster home/care provider.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The agency did not provide all known medical information to the foster parent.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/27/ 2022 I spoke with Foster Parent X by telephone. Foster Parent X reported
the agency did not share all known information to her about Child A on 6/30/2021.
She did not know Child A had medical problems, that would require extensive medical
appointments with doctors and physical therapists. The agency made it seem as if
Child A’s case was easy. The agency advised that Child A was living with her sister
in an aunt’s home; and because of some behavioral issues that were coming up
7

between the girls they needed to separate the siblings. The agency told her Child A
was age four, but behaved like a two-year-old, who has a bad temper. On 7/14/2021
the agency provided her with more information about Child A’s needs. The agency
told her Child A needed physical therapy, speech therapy, and then they said she
needed more services and required weekly visitation with Child A’s mother. Foster
Parent X reported this was her first time fostering and she did not know all that
fostering would entail. She acknowledged she was oriented to the agency’s foster
care program, and she attended PRIDE training. She said, fostering became
overwhelming, affected parenting of her own child; and so, she requested Child A’s
removal from her home. She said the removal occurred on 11/10/2021.
On 2/2/2022 I spoke with Program Manager 2 onsite, and Director 1 was available
by telephone, about the complaint. I interviewed FCW 3, and Licensing Supervisor
(LS) 4 about the allegations onsite on 2/2/2022.
 FCW 3 reported that on 6/30/2021 Foster Parent X was provided Child A’s
medical passport, Emergency Medicaid card and the agency’s on call
contact number. Additionally, on 6/30/2021, FCW 3 and LS 4 spoke with
Foster Parent X regarding Child A’s case. They informed Foster Parent X
of several appointments Child A has to attend, inclusive of the dentist, and
the referrals for occupational and physical therapy, which would then
require attendance at those services: and an assessment for therapy.
The foster parent understood from what was shared it meant that Child A
would require ongoing appointments and services. On 6/30/2021 Child A
also had an office visit with her mother and sister; and the agency had the
Child A’s mother to share information with Foster Parent X related to Child
A’s likes/dislikes and what encourages Child A. FCW 3 reported she also
spoke specifically with Foster Parent X about the time and commitment
fostering Child A would require. Foster Parent X agreed to the placement
and initially had no concerns with caring for Child A. FCW 3
acknowledged there came a time that Foster Parent X expressed concern
with all that was involved in fostering Child A. Those concerns came after
the school year started. At that time, Child A as well as Foster Parent X’s
own child school were physically back in school (they were not as
restricted as prior due to COVID). Foster Parent X became frustrated by
Child A’s continued appointments, all that came with fostering, Foster
Parent X’s life activities, and her children ongoing commitments. Foster
Parent X missed several physical therapy appointments for Child A. The
agency arranged for some transporting for Child A to appointments and
assisted with dental appointment scheduling. Additionally, LS 4 met with
Foster Parent X on more than one occasions to provide support to Foster
Parent X.
FCW 3 gave me a copy of the information she provided Foster Parent X. This
information was inclusive of:
8

 The agency’s Foster Care Re-Placement checklist dated 7/8/2021(which
Foster Parent X had also provided), signed by a case worker and supervisor
(neither signature was legible) as well as the foster parent for 7/14/2021. The
document also indicated the reason for Child A’s placement in care;
additionally, why Child A was being replaced; and her educational and
medical needs, while listing speech, occupational and physical therapy
needs; along with behavioral and emotional issues and a therapy referral.
 A Placement Outline and Information Record (DHS-3307), ( that Foster
Parent X had also provided) which indicated Child A’s previous placements,
known siblings first names; known history of abuse/neglect; physical
considerations (around illnesses, health problems, medications, allergies, etc.
this section mentioned Child A’s speech delay, and possible developmental
delay); emotional issues and behaviors (inclusive of “tantrums, crying,
screaming, and refusing to go somewhere”) and other known information
which might be helpful related to Child A. This document also outlined
services to be provided within the next 30 days, and indicated speech,
physical and occupational assessments, and scheduling. Also, listed was the
need for dental cleaning and examine. This document listed Child A’s
placement dated as 7/8/2021 and was signed 7/14/2021 by the same parties
as the Foster Care Re-Placement document.
 LS 4’s reporting about this allegation was similar to FCW 3’s reporting. She
reported they told Foster Parent X about Child A’s special needs, speech
therapist needs; and that Child A may need additional services because Child
A was not getting all she needed in her prior placement. Foster Parent X
spoke with Child A’s mother about Child A’ special needs. Foster Parent X
was clearly aware of services Child A needed and what more may be
required in the future because of those needs. LS 4 reported as they got
more information on services for Child A that information was relayed to
Foster Parent X.
Reviewed:
 The Placement Outline and Replacement checklist as indicated within this
report.
 MISACWIC case record for Child A which showed information as reported by
FCW 3 and LS 4 pertaining to the information and discussion with Foster
Parent X about Child A’s history and needs.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
9

(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment
for the foster child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not reside in the foster
home.
ANALYSIS: The foster parent admitted that she was provided initial
information about Child A on 6/30/2021 and more extensive
information about Child A needs on 7/14/2021. Evidence
presented by the agency staff and case records showed Foster
Parent X was provided information related to Child A’s known
history at the time, inclusive of information about Child A’s
health, and other know information which would enable the
foster parent to provide Child A and the foster family a safe,
stable, and healthy environment.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The agency failed to report suspected abuse.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/27/2022 I spoke with Foster Parent X by telephone. Foster Parent X did not
give details on this allegation. She reported FCW 3 failed to make a protective
service report when the child said her mom touched her, “poo poo,” (vagina), and
that she was whipped by her former foster mother Ms. N. Foster Parent X did not
report when these allegations were made to FCW 3.
FCW 3 denied the allegations. She said Foster Parent X never disclosed a time that
Child A reported Child A’s mom touched her “poo poo”. Nor that a past foster parent
whupped Child A. FCW 3 reported there was a time Foster Parent X called to say
Child A said someone touched Child A’s leg, but not specifically who, when or where
that happened. Foster Parent X then began grilling Child A with questions. FCW 3
recalled a report from Foster Parent X went from someone touching Child A’s leg to
Child A allegedly indicating FCW 3 drove Child A to her mom’s. That while at the
mom’s Child A had gotten dirty and inappropriate touching happen then. FCW 3
advised she was at that visit with Child A. Child A had gotten dirty and Child A’s
mother gave her a bath. FCW 3 was at the door, nothing inappropriate occurred.
FCW 3 advised that one of the reasons connected to Child A’s replacement from
Child A’s prior foster care placement was because that caregiver was being
investigated by children services. The caregiver requested Child A’s and Child A’s
sister’s immediate removal, which lead to Child A’s placement with Foster Parent X.
10

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12214 Compliance with 1975 PA 238.
An agency shall develop a written plan and implement the
plan to assure compliance with 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621,
and known as the child protection law.
ANALYSIS: The foster parent did not provide detail information about the
allegations. The agency denied such allegations being made to.
There is insufficient evidence to support the allegations or a
failure to report to children services.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The foster parent was not paid for a period of days in July 2021; and did not receive
the DOC as the agency told her she would.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/27/ 2022 I spoke with Foster Parent X by telephone. Foster Parent X
reported she was not paid a $5.00 per day DOC (Difficult of Care) rate for Child A
which was to start 7/14/2021. Foster Parent X reported not knowing about a DOC, or
that Child A was eligible for such until FCW 3 told her. FCW 3 told she was
approved for the DOC. Foster Parent X inquired about the payment several times.
Eventually the agency told her they don’t handle DOC’s, DHHS (Department of
Health and Human Services) must approve it. She reported, sometime after
November 2, 2021, she put everything in a letter about the lack of payment and she
asked for Child A’s removal from her home. She never received the DOC rate for
Child A. Nor did she know whether she was ever approved for such a rate. I
explained DOCs, why and how rates are approved/paid by the department. Foster
Parent X continued to state the agency told her she was approved.
Foster Parent X also reported not being pay for fostering days of 7/8/2021 through
7/31/2021. She reported having a few telephones and or email conversations with
the agency about this. She spoke or communicated with FCW 3, LS 4, Foster Care
Supervisor (FCS) 7 and another person she was referred to (whom she couldn’t
recall). Sometime in August 2021, the agency advised her they didn’t have a vendor
number for her, and she emailed that to them. However, another person, whom,
Foster Parent X didn’t identify told her that was not reason she had not received the
check. Sometime in October she was told the check was deposited into her bank
account. When she advised she never received the funds, the agency said the
check was mailed, and it was showing as not cashed. She was advised, she needed
to request a replacement check. She reported this matter is still unresolved and her
last contact with that agency about it was in early November 2021. Foster Parent X
reported complaining about this matter to the department now because the agency
11

made a complaint against her license, and is seeking to revoke her license, when
these are things, the agency did not do.
On 2/2/2022, I spoke with Program Manager 2 onsite, and Director 1 was available
by telephone. I interviewed FCW 3 and LS 4 about this allegation onsite on
2/2/2022 as well.
 Program Manager 2 and Director 1 advised the agency was informed by
Foster Parent X sometime in September 2021 that Foster Parent X did not
get her July 2021 foster care payment. Program Manager 2 advised the
check for the July 2021 payment was sent out on 8/5/2022; and it was
apparently not cashed. The agency requires that the foster parent sign an
affidavit to assert that they did not receive the check. Foster Parent X has
refused to do so several times. The last discussion with Foster Parent X
about this occurred sometime in November; and the agency was waiting for
Foster Parent X to come sign the document. Program Manager 2 reported
that as it relates to Foster Parent X not receiving a DOC there was an issue
with Foster Parent not signing the child’s treatment plan. She said, FCW 3
would be better able to speak to this issue.
 FCW 3 reported what Program 2 had relayed pertaining to Foster Parent X’s
missed check in the mail; and Foster Parent X needing to sign an affidavit.
FCW 3 spoke more to the issue of the DOC. She denied telling Foster Parent
X that Child A was approved for the DOC. Nor did she represent it as if it was
a done deal. She discussed the process and criteria for requesting a DOC.
She let Foster Parent X know what would make Child A eligible; that it has to
do with extra care Foster Parent X has to provide and show; and that DHHS
must approve the DOC. She said she went over the DOC document with
Foster Parent X. DHHS did not approve the DOC request because the
current Parent Agency Treatment Plan Agreement (PATPA) at the time
(7/17/2021) did not reflect what was being reported. Additionally, Foster
Parent X had refused to sign that PTAPA and did not sign the October 2021
PATPA. Foster Parent X was not understanding that she needed to comply
with those things. FCW 3 tried explaining to DHHS why the paperwork was
not lining up. In mid-October 2021, FCW 3 was communicating with and
apprising Foster Parent X of what more was needed from Foster Parent X for
the DOC to be get processed and hopefully approved. DHHS’s hadn’t
officially denied the DOC, but it had not been approved either. FCW 3
apprised Foster Parent X that in order for the agency to re-request the DOC,
Foster Parent X needed to sign the new DOC document and the last two
PATPAs. Foster Parent X stopped communicating with the agency and
nothing more could be done on the DOC matter. Child A entered a new
foster home on 11/10/2021.
 LS 4 addressed the foster car payment aspect of the allegation. She reported
with regards to Foster Parent X not receiving payment for 7/8/2021-
12

7/31/2021, Foster Parent X had a check that was lost. FS 4 tried to help get
payment for Foster Parent A, because Foster Parent X had done the agency
a favor by taking Child A into her home. Foster Parent X worked with them
